title.value: When Do Graph Neural Networks Help with Node Classification? Investigating the Impact of Homophily Principle on Node Distinguishability
title.justification: This information is present at the beginning of the paper, providing the main title of the research.
title.quote: When Do Graph Neural Networks Help with Node Classification? Investigating the Impact of Homophily Principle on Node Distinguishability

extractions.description: This paper investigates the relationship between homophily in graphs and the performance of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) versus traditional Neural Networks (NNs) in node classification tasks. It challenges the commonly held belief that homophily is the primary reason for the superior performance of GNNs and introduces new models and metrics to better understand the conditions under which GNNs are advantageous.

type.justification: The paper includes empirical evaluations and experiments that indicate the impact of homophily and node distinguishability on the performance of GNNs, common in empirical studies.
type.quote: Experiments indicate that it is significantly more effective than the existing homophily metrics on revealing the advantage and disadvantage of graph-aware modes on both synthetic and benchmark real-world datasets.

name.justification: The paper mainly focuses on GNNs and their performance in relation to node classification and homophily.
name.quote: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have gained popularity in recent years as a powerful tool for graph-based machine learning tasks.

name.justification: The primary application discussed here is node classification, particularly in the context of graph data and neural networks.
name.quote: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) over Neural Networks on node classification tasks.

name.justification: A significant portion of the paper is dedicated to evaluating the impact of homophily on the performance metrics of GNNs.
name.quote: Homophily principle, i.e., nodes with the same labels are more likely to be connected, has been believed to be the main reason for the performance superiority of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) over Neural Networks on node classification tasks.

name.justification: GCN is a well-known type of graph neural network often used in many GNN studies, including this paper.
name.quote: GCN: Y = Softmax(Âsym ReLU(Âsym XW0 ) W1 )

is_contributed.justification: GCN is a well-established model in the Graph Neural Network field and is not an original contribution of this paper.

name.justification: Cora is a classic benchmark dataset for evaluating graph neural network models, frequently used in such contexts.
name.quote: In each time, we randomly split the data into training/validation/test sets with a ratio of 60%/20%/20%. For the 100 samples, we conduct T-test for the means of two independent samples of scores, and obtain the corresponding p-values. The test results and model performance comparisons are shown in Table 1 (See more experimental tests on state-of-the-art model in Appendix H).
